label: Letter from Sidney Jennings Legendre, February 20, 1948
description: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his brother, Armant Legendre, recounting a story of he and Gertrude going to the wrong location for the Forestry Association Convention, apologizing for a misconstrued remark he made upon his last visit to New Orleans, and instructing Armant to rest more.

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his brother, Armant Legendre, recounting a story of he and Gertrude going to the wrong location for the Forestry Association Convention, apologizing for a misconstrued remark he made upon his last visit to New Orleans, and instructing Armant to rest more.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
February 20, 1948
Mr. Armant Legendre
433 Gravier Street
New Orleans, La.
Dear Armant,
This letter of thanks to you is very much de-
layed due to the traveling we have been doing. af-
ter leaving New Orleans, Morris and I went on to
Charlotte, and there in a weak mement,due to our ex-
ertions at Mardi Gras,we took over the franchise for
Drink-O-Mat in North Carolina in addition to holding
it in South Carolina. We spent most of Wednesday
night talking with lawyers, and then on Thursday
closed the deal,and made a quick survey of the thea-
ters in that part of the country. we then came down
here, amd Morris went back to Aiken, where he was to
stay Sunday night and then return to Washington for
his new post. However, on reaching there he was
threatened with pneumonia, and has been in bed in
Aiken over since. I speak to him on the telephone
occasionally, and he still is feeling quite badly.
Now for the big story that you will really
like. For some time I have been priming Gertrude
for a trip to Valdosta, Georgia, where there was to
be a forestry association convennion. I was suppose
to make a speach there, and also wanted to hear all
the other speach makers to find out what was the lat-
est things in forestry. Gertrude said she would go
and accordingly we set out on Tuesday in the car to
motor the 300 miles. We arrived in Valdosta about
8.30 in the evening, and I asked a man on the corner
where the Hotel Heidelburg was, as this is where I
Had my reservations. He said he had never heard of
it, and I muttered what a stupid man, and went on
until I found a policeman and asked him where the
hotel was. Be also said that he had never heard of
it. Gertrude, by now, was a little bit angry and
[End Page 1]
-2-
very hungry, and said lets get something te eat
so we went into a little restaurant. While there,
she said, "I think you have the wrong town". I
laughed at this, but went out to the car and brought
in my letter file just to prove te her that we were
in the right town. In opening up the file, I read
the letter from the Forestry Association whose head-
quarters is in Valdosta. It said, "Dear Mr. Legendre:
This is to anounce that we are having our annual meet-
ing in Jackson Missippippi".When I read that Gertrude
let out such a shout that you oould have heard it
back at Medway. She roared with laughter for at least
half an hour, and was absolutely unable to eat any-
thing, as everytime she started she would laugh again.
We discovered that Jackson, Miss.  was 550 miles
away from us, and that our whole trip was in vain.
We slept in a tourist court that might and motored
on to Thomasville the next day to see Jock Whitney's
place, and speak to his manager about quail and tim-
ber, but the main point of our trip of course was
lost. Now when ever I say anything, Gertrude just
says, "Remember Valdosta⁵.
I was terribly sorry that you became so tired
on my last light there, and I wanted to explain a
remark that I made in case you took it the wrong
way, as I think you did. You will recall that I had
said, 'If he is in such a bad temper, let him go
home.⠂y this I was critizing your temper, but the
fact that everyone was continually trying to push
and pull you to keep going and to come along. They
would take turns urging you, and It made me furious
because when one is tired there is nothing worst than
being forced and begged to come on and have a good
time. That is why I told them to let you go home
and step begging you to stay. It was not in any
sense a critism of your temper, because I flared up
a little later in the evening quite a bit myself
due to being exhausted. Honestly Armant, I think
that you are foolish to let yourself bark as hard
as you do,and than let them push you into a little
room like that, and take away tose conforts of liv-
ing that you deserve. Children really do not ap-
preciate it, and though you may think you are giv-
ing them a good time actuallyy it makes very little
difference and all you do is to suffer. Also I
[End Page 2]
-3-
think you become as ever as you were, amd as a result
perhaps suffers relapse of your eye or stomach is
ridiculous. For what purpose is it, absolutely none
and strongly advise you to take that fine front
room, and say this is my room for ever and ever, and
nobody else can ever have it. I would also refuse
to go out when you are tired, and I know that you
realise that Morris and I do not want or expect you
to out with us when we are down there if you are not
feeling well. We certainly would not go out with
you if we were tired, but would go to bed as you well
know.
Thank you ever so much though for everything
you did for me while I was in New Orleans,and all
the trouble that you took to get me into Syntax,
and showing me around. I really did appreciate your
coming down to the padle, as I know you did not want
to and it is such fun seeing you that I always love
my visits to New Orleans.
I know that it is almost useless to ask you
to come up here, but perhaps somehow business will
bring you into our part or the world this spring,
and you will stay with me and drink a little corn
whisky. We are all breaking up so quickly that I
want to grasp every possible moment together, be-
cause these are the times I emjoy myself most.
Love,
Sidney
[End Page 3]
[appears to be an alternative Page 3]
-3-
Am afraid your stomach and eyes will go back on
you if you let yourself get so over tired.
Thank you ever so much though for everything
you did for me while I was in New Orleans,and all
the trouble that you took to get me into Syntax,
and showing me around. I really did appreciate your
coming down to the padle, as I know you did not want
to and it is such fun seeing you that I always love
my visits to New Orleans.
I know that it is almost useless to ask you
to come up here, but perhaps somehow business will
bring you into our part or the world this spring,
and you will stay with me and drink a little corn
whisky. We are all breaking up so quickly that I
want to grasp every possible moment together, be-
cause these are the times I emjoy myself most.
Love,
Sidney
[End Page 4]
